choices.B: The first packets from Toronto to London are routed through Hub 1 then to Hub 2.
choices.A: London generates an IKE information message that contains the Toronto public IP address.
choices.D: Toronto needs to establish a site-to-site tunnel with Hub 2 to bypass Hub 1.
choices.C: Traffic from Toronto to London triggers the dynamic negotiation of a direct site-to-site VPN.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.

//IMG//


Two hub-and-spoke groups are connected through a site-to-site IPsec VPN between Hub 1 and Hub 2. The administrator configured ADVPN on both hub-and-spoke groups.

Which two outcomes are expected if a user in Toronto sends traffic to London? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
the answer is A. The question is about memeber utilization. 
D is for interface utilzation. There is no mention of INTERFACE in the question. See 7.2 P322

Selected Answer: D
A. diagnose sys sdwan sla-log → Incorrect, because this command does not exist in FortiGate CLI.
B. diagnose sys sdwan log → Incorrect, as it only provides general SD-WAN log information, not SLA-based utilization statistics.
C. diagnose sys sdwan health-check → Incorrect, as it provides real-time results of SD-WAN health checks but does not show historical statistics.
Thus, Option D is the correct answer because it retrieves historical SLA-based statistics for SD-WAN interfaces over the last 10 minutes.

Selected Answer: D
D. Page 322.
Correct answer is D, Study Guide Page 322, the key word in here is Member Utilization.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct as stated on page 322 in the Study Guide.

questions.question_text: Which diagnostic command can you use to show the member utilization statistics measured by performance SLAs for the last 10 minutes?

choices.A: FortiGate continues routing the sessions with no SNAT, over port2.
choices.B: FortiGate updates the gateway information of the sessions with SNAT so that they use port1 instead of port2.
choices.C: FortiGate flags the sessions as dirty.
choices.D: FortiGate performs a route lookup for the original traffic only.

E. Internet service database (ISDB) address object → ISDB objects can be used in policies but are not a direct SD-WAN rule traffic-matching criterion.

questions.question_text: Which three matching traffic criteria are available in SD-WAN rules? (Choose three.)
What is the route-tag setting in an SD-WAN rule used for?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct. This is described on page 141 in the 7.2 Study Guide.

comments.content: Correction - page 141 and 142 describes the use of route-tags.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
https://community.fortinet.com/t5/FortiGate/Technical-Tip-When-to-use-BGP-route-tag-in-SD-WAN-rule-s/ta-p/229720

Selected Answer: D
I'm voting for D. The admin guide says: SD-WAN rules can use Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) learned routes as dynamic destinations.

Selected Answer: A
I think the answer is A. Route tags are not specific to BGP. BGP does have them but so does OSPF. Communities are specific to BGP but route tags can be used in any routing protocol.

Selected Answer: D
SG p141: "Configure SD-WAN *rules* to steer traffic to members only if routes have a specific route-tag."
Agree with Cyril - although A says the largely same thing as D, route-tag specifically get used by the SD-WAN rule to determine next-hop (i.e., destination).
SG p 142 shows "how an administrator can use [route-]tags in SD-WAN rules."
This is a crappy question.

Both A & D are vague, but they're saying the same thing, with D being more SDWAN-ish.
we use tags so that we can use them as match conditions when we steer traffic to them that's the reason you'd go through the trouble of tagging/colouring your route prefixes. Because SDWAN can change routes for any number of reason, we want these specifi routes to be easily identifiable so we can route/steer traffic towards them in a specific way.
#sorry..that was a mouthful

Selected Answer: D
D: once you setup a route tag on the config service under the sdwan section then it appears as the destination in the sdwan rule. 

also: Route tag is one of the criteria you can use to determine which traffic matches an SD-WAN rule

Selected Answer: A
If you look at the image on page 141 it states "The rule can only use routes that have the tag set" - the answer is A. D is talking about setting a destination when the route-tag is simply defining what routes are able to be used.
D is correct, study guide page 141

choices.A: To indicate the routes that can be used for routing SD-WAN traffic.
choices.D: To indicate the destination of a rule based on learned BGP prefixes.
choices.C: To indicate the routes for health check probes.
choices.B: To indicate the members that can be used to route SD-WAN traffic.
